title: 104_s1241
content: The Public Broadcasting Financial Independence and Family Viewing Act of 1995 aims to ensure that programs suitable for family viewing are broadcasted throughout the day without the use of federal funds for indecent or nudity-inclusive content. Additionally, public broadcasting is required to provide educational, cultural, informational, and entertaining programming in the public interest. SEC. 5. SPECTRUM FLEXIBILITY. The Commission will allow public broadcast license holders to use their spectrum for ancillary services, ensuring proceeds benefit public broadcasting and fees are at market rates. SEC. 6. SCHEDULE FLEXIBILITY. SEC. 6. SCHEDULE FLEXIBILITY. The Commission will allow public broadcast license holders to provide non-public broadcast programming for a fee between 1 a.m. and 6 a.m., ensuring proceeds benefit public broadcasting and fees are at market rates. SEC. 7. ENHANCED UNDERWRITING. Amendments to title 47 allow for the promotion of products or services through a call to action or the provision of price information. SEC. 8. SATELLITE, COMMON CARRIER AND OTHER FORMS OF PROGRAM DISTRIBUTION. Public Broadcasting programming can be distributed for a fee via various technologies, with proceeds benefiting public broadcasting exclusively. Public Broadcasting programming can be distributed through various technologies for a fee, with proceeds benefiting public broadcasting exclusively. The Commission may approve frequency exchanges between public and commercial broadcasters for the benefit of the national public broadcasting system. Agreements for programming should include provisions for public broadcasting to share in benefits from ancillary products related to the broadcast. The General Accounting Office will review the operations of public broadcasting entities and make recommendations for improvement. They will also study the feasibility of merging public broadcasting with international broadcasting operations. Additionally, educational rates will be addressed. The General Accounting Office will conduct a feasibility study on merging public broadcasting operations with international broadcasting of the US Government. Public broadcast licensees may qualify for educational telecommunication service rates for providing public broadcasting.
